Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Tools and databases for network-based plant systems biology with applications to understanding plant-virus interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to improve the tools for making models for networks of interacting molecules in the small mustard plant, Arabidopsis. To demonstrate the effectiveness of these methods, the resources developed in this research will be used to study the plant's immunity to a virus infection under several conditions. Understanding how and when the virus overcomes the plants defenses gives us a handle on controlling an important pathogen of crop plants in the Southern US, with benefits such as better yield and less pesticide use. While biologists can measure the presence and amounts of tens of thousands of molecules in a cell all at once, understanding how they are connected, the 'networks' or 'systems' that lead to function, is a much harder problem. The huge amounts of measurements have to be properly managed so they are usable, and additional information has to be correctly added: it is important to track how amounts of one type of molecule change over time and not mix up different things. It is also important to understand which parts of the cell affect one another: those that belong to a functionally connected pathway (or network), and which are independent of each other. For example, plants have complicated mechanisms to defend themselves against biological and environmental stresses. Signaling pathways cause the plant's response, and they are influenced by internal genetic factors as well as the external ones that are more easily observed. If every protein (or other molecule) inside the cell that plays a part in carrying and interpreting the signal is known then very effective predictions about the final response are possible. However, plant researchers don't know nearly as much about the molecules in their organisms as is available to many researchers studying animals, which means there are a lot of missing nodes. That makes it hard to come up with a specific prediction that can be tested: this research aims to overcome this problem for selected plant pathways, to showcase what is possible when there is sufficient information. This project will actively engage students in interdisciplinary research, with a particular focus on recruiting underrepresented groups. The University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) is a Hispanic-Serving Institution.


This project has the following four specific aims: 1) to construct genome-wide transcriptional regulatory network in Arabidopsis with validation in immune-responsive genes; 2) to improve the prediction of protein-protein interactions and identification of defense subnetworks in Arabidopsis; 3) to perform network-based analysis of Arabidopsis immune-responsive network in order to decipher the role of plant viral RNA silencing suppressors in plant immunity; and 4) to provide online databases and analytic tools for network-based plant systems biology studies. This project promises to significantly improve network-based analysis with several innovative ideas. First, the proposed approaches focus on improving accuracy of predictions for individual genes by defining a network neighborhood for each node and testing for enrichment in the neighborhood for each node. This is in contrast to most existing approaches that make predictions on gene modules (within- or cross-species) and therefore lack quality control on an individual gene level. Second, combining protein-protein interaction network, gene co-expression network, and sample-sample network, this research provides an example to analyze such networks in a dynamic context automatically defined by the global transcriptomic landscape; as such, this study is expected to provide more specific predictions that can be experimentally tested. In addition, integration of computational tools to characterize defense-related network structure in this work will significantly improve the ability to study the role of co-regulated networks of genes in any number of processes, including but not limited to genes implicated in both plant and animal disease, cancer or stem cell biology, or tissue specificity of gene expression. The results of the project can be found at http://cs.utsa.edu/~jruan/plantnet/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to develop computational tools and methods for building models for networks of interacting molecules in Arabidopsis (a small mustard plant) and other species. To demonstrate the effectiveness of these methods, the resources developed were used to study the plant's immunity to a virus infection, i.e., how the genes in the host and the virus interact with each other and change their activity levels as a response or counter-response. Understanding how and when the virus overcomes the plants defenses gives us a handle on controlling an important pathogen of crop plants in the US, with benefits such as better yield and less pesticide use. The activity level of a gene in the cell is regulated at multiple levels, including transcriptional, where the activity (expression) of each gene is controlled by a network of special genes called transcription factors (TFs). In this project, we developed tools for improving the modeling and characterization of such TF networks. For example, we developed algorithms to model the binding of TFs to their target DNA sequences, using the so-call multiple-instance machine learning paradigm (Gao & Ruan, Bioinformatics 2017), which resulted in higher accuracy and better interpretability of the models. The method was applied to several hundred TFs, and outperformed conventional algorithms for >90% of TF tested.  Additionally, we developed a convenient tool to read images of TF binding sites from old papers and turn them into mathematical models (matrices) in plain text format to speed up the scanning of TF binding sites (Gao, Liu & Ruan, BMC Genomics 2017). To enable comparative analysis of multiple gene networks, we developed a method to identify the most salient differences (Liu & Ruan, JBCB 2017). We applied the algorithm to chromatin interaction networks (mathematical models for chromosome structures), and identified interesting structural changes strongly correlated with DNA regulatory regions. In addition, to help characterize subnetworks of genes in response to environmental / pathogenic changes, we developed an algorithm to identify statistically significant functional terms, taking into consideration of the network structure (Liu & Ruan, Genes, 2017).

 

Utilizing these tools, we identified combinatory patterns in Arabidopsis gene regulatory networks by combining protein-DNA/protein-protein interactions and gene expression data. The result is a high-fidelity network involving more than 500 TFs, and the associated conditional specificity of the interactions (Zand et al, ICCABS 2018). We analyzed the resulting network, and verified that the predicted interactions have higher than expected percentage of known relationships (e.g., co-family members and functional similarities). We identified groups of TFs whose target genes were co-expressed under specific conditions such as environmental stress or pathogen infection. We also analyzed 43 genomes in the genus of bipartite begomovirus, which are responsible for worldwide economic damages to important crops such as tomatoes, beans, squash, cassava and cotton, and identified several host factors, including TCP24, that may together be involved in plant-virus interactions. Our experimental results show that TCP24 binds the coating protein promoter in several virus, validating our computational prediction (Guerrero et al., Frontiers in Plant Sciences, 2020). Additional bioinformatics analysis showed that other host factors have known links to pathogen resistance responses, and suggested that these factors may achieve the desired regulation by changing the global landscaping of host chromatin, a novel finding that we are exploring further outside of the scope of the NSF award.

 

Finally, the project resulted in several machine learning algorithms that have broader applications. These include a clustering algorithms that can help identify novel cell / gene groups using data from a technology to take measurement at single cell resolution (Zand & Ruan, BioRxiv 2021), an algorithm for recovering the spatial organization of cells utilizing only data obtained from individual cells dissociated from a tissue (Zand & Ruan, F1000 Research, 2020), as well as an algorithm for predicting phenotypes (e.g., disease outcomes) based on gene expression and is suitable for personalized medicine in cancer treatment (Gao, Zand & Ruan, DSAA 2019).

 

In broad impacts, the project provided invaluable opportunities for many graduate and undergraduate students to receive inter-disciplinary STEM training. As a result, three PhD dissertations have been completed, and four PhD students are currently involved in the project. Among them, three are female, and one is an Africa American. PhD student Lu Liu joined North Dakota State University as an assistant professor. PhD student Maryam Zand joined J. Craig Venter Institute as a Senior Bioinformatician. Thanks to the diverse training from the project, PhD student Zhen Gao joined eMetrics as a data scientist. The project also provided training opportunity for two master students (both are female) and five undergraduate students (three female, one community college, and two Hispanic).The project also resulted in multiple software tools and web services freely available to the research community. The tools found applications in several studies in collaborators' labs and resulted in several high-impact publications and pre-prints.
